za.ac.salt.pipt.common
Class Grid

java.lang.Object
  za.ac.salt.pipt.common.Grid
Direct Known Subclasses:
Filter, GenericSpectrum
public class Grid
extends java.lang.Object

A base class for 1-D numeric grids. We provide basic numerical algorithms, such as adding, scaling, and cubic spline interpolation.

Note: comments will often name Angstroms as the x-value. This is for concreteness in descriptions; actually, the x-values may represent any quantity.

A Grid is characterized by 3 integers:

  • j: the starting value; the first abcissa is at 2**j Angstroms
  • k: the resolution; there are 2**k Angstroms per bin.
  • m: the range; the data cover 2**m Angstroms. There are 2**m/2**k, or 2**(m-k) bins in the Grid.

    Parameterizing a Grid in this way is useful. The most frequent grid operations involve multiplying one by another, e.g. scaling a spectrum by a filter's loss-function. To do this, the grids' bins must be commensurate. If they are not, then we can invoke an expensive area-preserving regridding of one or the other, but we must avoid doing this very often to maintain good performance.

    With our parameterization, grid bins are commensurate if the k's agree, and the offset of one grid with respect to the other is always an integral number of bins. Grid-on-grid operations depend only on k, and changing k is very fast (see point 4 below).

  • 1. Forcing a 2**j start value helps alignment between grids; no fractional offsets.
  • 2. Forcing 2**k Angstroms per bin is *really* useful. The step size, being a power of 2 (e.g. 4, 2, 1, 0.5, 0.25, 0.125, 0.0625...) can always be represented exactly in a computer. Repetitive summation of the step size does not accrue roundoff errors.
  • 3. Treating resolution and range independently reflects usage: We will more often want to change the resolution (k) of a grid, perhaps to make it commensurate with another grid, than we will want to change the range (e.g. extending by adding zeroes, or constraining by throwing away data).
  • 4. Changing the resolution with binary step sizes just means splitting bins apart in pairs, or adding them together in pairs. This is really fast. Further changes in resolution can be done recursively.

    The use of 2**j as the starting x-value deserves a closer look. Consider the case of two Grids with equal k-values. The bins are the same size. The two Grids may be offset, though, with one starting at 2000 Angstroms and the other at 3000. This example offset causes no difficulty, because the bins still match up in the region of overlap. But consider, for example, the case of k=2 (4 Angstroms per bin) with one Grid starting at 2000 Angstroms and the other at 2001. The bins of each are the same size, but one can't slide one with respect to the other to align both bins and Angstroms. When bins align, Angstroms don't, and vice versa. To avoid this, the starting values need to be multiples of 2**k (and j >= k);

    Field Detail

    DEFAULT_LB_STARTING_VALUE

    public static final int DEFAULT_LB_STARTING_VALUE
    the default abscissa starting value, given as the binary logarithmic value (i.e. the value of 11 corresponds to a "real" value of 2 ^ 11 = 2048)

    See Also:
    Constant Field Values

    DEFAULT_LB_RESOLUTION

    public static final int DEFAULT_LB_RESOLUTION
    the default abscissa resolution (i.e. the interval length per bin), given as the binary logarithmic value (i.e. the value of -4 corresponds to a "real" bin length of 2 ^ -4 = 0.0625)

    See Also:
    Constant Field Values

    DEFAULT_LB_RANGE

    public static final int DEFAULT_LB_RANGE
    the default abscissa range (i.e. difference between its boundaries), given as the binary logarithmic value (i.e. the value of 13 corresponds to a "real" range of 2 ^13 = 8192)

    See Also:
    Constant Field Values

    y

    public double[] y
    the ordinate values (public, not private, for fast access)

    reset

    public void reset(int lbStartingValue,
                  int lbResolution,
                  int lbRange)
    Resets the various grid variables according to the given parameters. The dirty bit is set so that the second derivatives will be recalculated later on.

    Parameters:
    lbStartingValue - the starting value of the abscissa, given as the binary logarithmic value
    lbResolution - the abscissa interval length per bin, given as the binary logarithmic value
    lbRange - the overall abscissa range, given as the binary logarithmic value

    reset

    public double reset(double x0,
                    double dx,
                    double range)
    Resets the various grid variables to match the given parameters. If necessary, the range is adjusted. The resulting range is returned. Find j such that 2**j is the next power of 2 smaller than x0. Find k such that 2**k is the next power of 2 smaller than dx. Find m such that 2**m is the next power of 2 higher than range.

    Parameters:
    x0 - the starting value of the abscissa
    dx - the length of a bin
    range - the abscissa range
    Returns:
    the adjusted range

    read

    public int read(double[] xdata,
                double[] ydata,
                java.io.InputStream inputStream)
    Reads data into arrays from an input stream. The number of data points is returned.

    Parameters:

    ydata - the ordinate values
    inputStream - the input stream from which the data is read
    Returns:
    the number of data points
    Throws:

    resample

    public void resample(int lbResolution)
    Changes the resolution of a grid. Note that if we are already at the right resolution, we do nothing and there is no penalty.

    Parameters:
    lbResolution - the new resolution, given as the binary logarithmic value

                     int ndata)

    Parameters:

    ydata - the ordinate data
    ndata - the number of data points

    write

    public void write(java.io.OutputStream outputStream)
    Writes the grid values to the given output stream. Each line is of the form "x y", where x and y denote the abscissa and the corresponding ordinate value, respectively.

    Parameters:
    outputStream - the output stream

    Parameters:
